item.title: Time Filter
item.description: Barry Schwartz wrote The paradox of choice in 2004, and its relevance is indubitable today in 2020. The argument that probably most of us would be happy if there are a lesser number of choices has increased its relevance over time. The current age is of an apparent abundance, and like the real devil, it doesn’t seem to be a problem. If anything, it feels like the happiest time of our lives because we need not think twice to get what we want. To all those who don’t think this is a real issue, this article is not for you. It is not an argument to prove the problem of abundance or the paradox of having a large number of choices. For others, one of my method to diminish the damage to my attention span, focus and happiness is by using time as a filter. This implies using a time threshold to decide whether to consume something or not.
